#â€‹575 â€” October 22, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

The Draft Go 1.26 Release Notes â€” Itâ€™s still early days for the under-development Go 1.26, due to land in February 2026, but thereâ€™s already a draft set of release notes covering enhancements most likely committed to the release so far, including newâ€™s support forÂ expressions.

The Go Team

The â€œ10xâ€ Commandments of Highly EffectiveÂ Go â€” John comes down from the mountain with ten Go commandments. The conceit may be cute, but these are essentially ten broad guidelines for Go developers, coupled with examples of adopting them inÂ GoLand.

John Arundel

Automate GitHub Actions Runner Updates with Claude â€” Forget about managing GitHub Actions runners and get back to writing code. Learn how Depot uses Claude to automatically handle all those pesky updates and how you can get faster, more stable CI/CD without theÂ headache.

Depot sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“Š JetBrains (creator of GoLand) has released the results of its latest 'State of Developer Ecosystem Report' with Go at #4 in its 'Language Promise Index' and #1 in 'languages developers want to adopt next.'

  • The popular Go-powered Caddy HTTPS server project is now 11 years old and Matt Holt shares some updates on next steps for the project's long-term maintenance.

  • Writing Better Go: Lessons from 10 Code Reviews is a fantastic set of slides from a recent talk by Konrad Reiche at GoLab 2025.

The Speed of Random Number Generators â€” There are several obvious options for generating random numbers in Go â€“ Daniel quickly compares their performance (spoiler: math/rand/v2 using PCG is theÂ winner).

Daniel Lemire

The 'Compare IP Subnets' Proposal â€” As part of his Accepted! series explaining upcoming changes to Go, Anton explains how Go 1.26 will make comparing IP subnets (e.g. 10.0.0.0/8) easier.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ“„ Parsing Financial News for Automated Trading Decisions â€“ But always remember, folks: â€œtime in the market beats timing the marketâ€ ;-) Paolo Galeone

ğŸ“„ JWT Authentication in Go with Gin â€“ With the end goal to work with Vonage in this case, but the principles can be usedÂ elsewhere. Benjamin Aronov (Vonage)

ğŸ“„ Durable Background Execution with Go and SQLite Dima Kotik

ğŸ“„ Subtest Grouping in Go Redowan Delowar

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

gotests: Automatically Generate Test Boilerplate From Code â€” Automatically creates table-driven tests from your source code by analyzing function and method signatures. This weekâ€™s v1.8.0 release adds complete support for generics, meaning gotests can generate tests for generic functions and methods on genericÂ types.

Charles Weill et al.

What Shopify, Figma, and Stripe Use for Pair Programming â€” Tuple is the most effective way to unblock PRs, make technical decisions, and polish or reviewÂ code.

Tuple sponsor

urfave/cli 3.1: A Declarative Way to Build Go CLI Apps â€” The manual outlines all of the key features, but think shell auto-completion, option parsing, help text, etc.

Jeremy Saenz and Contributors

go-torch: Torch-Like Deep Learning Framework in Go â€” Open-source deep learning framework built from the ground up in pureÂ Go.

Abinesh Mathivanan

go-nvtrust: NVIDIA GPU and NVSwitch Confidential Computing Attestation â€” This is niche! Itâ€™s a Go version of Nvidiaâ€™s nvTrust to manage â€˜Confidential Computingâ€™ attestation evidence from NVIDIAÂ GPUs.

Confident Security

  • ğŸ“ˆ go-echarts 2.6.5 â€“ Charting and data visualization library that uses ApacheÂ ECharts. You can see examples in theÂ docs.

  • ğŸ’¬ go-xmpp v0.2.18 â€“ XMPP client library. There's even a basic GUI chat app example in just 113 lines ofÂ code.

  • Hugo 0.152.0 â€“ The popular static site generator has changed its YAML-parsing library, so take care if you use the terms 'yes', 'no', 'on', 'off' or variants of those in your YAMLÂ files.

  • Lefthook 2.0 â€“ Fast and powerful Git hooks manager.

  • ğŸ¤– Gobot 2.6 â€“ Robotics / drones / IoTÂ framework.

ğŸ And one for fun..

superfile: Go-Powered Terminal-Based FileÂ Manager â€” A modern, well-styled (and theme-able) terminal based file manager app built atop Bubble Tea. GitHubÂ repo.

Yorukot

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹574 â€” October 15, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

15 Go Subtleties You May Not Already Know â€” A well written roundup of lesser-known Go features or idiosyncrasies thatâ€™s worth a skim even if only a few jump out at you. Or if you already know about them all, you can feel a warm glow for the rest of the day ğŸ˜ Topics include time.After, nil interfaces, and jsonâ€™s - tag.

Harrison Cramer

Get Oâ€™Reilly Book Data Engineering Design Patterns, Courtesy of Buf â€” Discover proven design patterns for building reliable, scalable data systems. This free Oâ€™Reilly ebook, courtesy of Buf, focuses on several important aspects of data engineering, including data ingestion, data quality, idempotency, andÂ more.

Buf sponsor

How Slow is Channel-Based Iteration? â€” The makers of the Go-powered Dolt database run an example involving iteration using two channel-based approaches, as well as iter.Pull. Conclusion? â€œThe haters are right: using channels for iteration isÂ slow.â€

Zach Musgrave

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.25.3 and 1.24.9 have been released. They're minor point releases which address a problem caused by an earlier security patch being overly restrictive when parsing X.509Â certificates.

  • The creator of the popular Lodash-like Lo library has started work on Ro, an attempt to bring the ReactiveX reactive programming model toÂ Go.

  • ğŸ§ It's been a long time since we linked to it, but if you'd also like to listen to Go news, the Cup o'Go podcast is still going out every week.

Gist of Go: Atomics â€” In Go, â€˜atomicsâ€™ are low-level synchronization primitives from sync/atomic for performing lock-free, thread-safe operations on shared memory values. Sometimes, race-free concurrency without a mutex really isÂ possible.

Anton Zhiyanov

A Modern Approach to Preventing CSRF/CORF in Go â€” Go 1.25 introduced a new http.CrossOriginProtection middleware that can help protect against cross-site and cross-origin forgery attacks using browser security headers instead ofÂ tokens.

Alex Edwards

ğŸ’¡ Simon Willison reflects further on the technique covered above.

ğŸ“„ CPU Cache-Friendly Data Structures in Go: 10x Speed with Same Algorithm â€“ When you need to squeeze out every bit of performance, keeping CPU caching in mind can make a bigÂ difference. Serge Skoredin

ğŸ“„ How to Get Started with GitHub Copilot CLI Andrea Griffiths (GitHub)

ğŸ“„ Organizing Go Tests Redowan Delowar

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Excelize 2.10: A Pure Go Way to Work with Excel Spreadsheets â€” A way to read and write XLAM / XLSM / XLSX / XLTM and XLTX files from Go. A long time library that keeps going from strength to strength. GitHubÂ repo.

QI-ANXIN GROUP

Sift: A Lightweight Terminal UI for Displaying Go Test Results â€” Pipe your verbose Go testing JSON output into this tool for navigable and collapsible test output so you can focus only on what matters to yourÂ situation.

Tim Tattersall

What Shopify, Tailwind, and Stripe Use for Pair Programming â€” Tuple is the most effective way to unblock PRs, make technical decisions, and polish or reviewÂ code.

Tuple sponsor

Oto 3.4: Low-Level Cross-Platform Sound Library â€” Used by the Ebitengine 2D game engine to play audio on a remarkable number of platforms from Windows, macOS and Linux to more intriguing options like the Nintendo Switch andÂ iOS.

Ebitengine

Goiaba: An Experimental Go Parser and Compiler in Rust â€” An experimental/work-in-progress Go parser and WebAssembly compiler written in Rust, being written largely as a learningÂ exercise.

Raphael Amorim

  • Huh 0.8 (above) â€“ Charm's library for building forms and prompts on the terminal. v0.8 lets you create and maintain your own Field types.

  • ğŸ•’ gocron 2.17 â€“ Job scheduling package for running Go functions at specifiedÂ intervals.

  • AWS Lambda for Go 1.50 â€“ Samples & tools for building on AWSÂ Lambda.

  • Go Micro 5.10 â€“ Popular Go microservicesÂ framework.

  • Buf 1.58 â€“ CLI tool for working with ProtocolÂ Buffers.

  • go-github 76.0 â€“ GitHub v3 API clientÂ library.

  • Redigo 1.9.3 â€“ Redis/Valkey client library.

qjs: Run JavaScript in Go â€” A new Cgo-free runtime option to integrate JavaScript into Go apps. Rather than bind to a native library, it uses a fork of QuickJS compiled to WebAssembly and then run under Wazero. You get ES2023 compatibility, sandboxing, zero-copy sharing of values between Go and JS, and the ability to expose Go functions to JS and viceÂ versa.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹572 â€” October 1, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Flight Recorder in Go 1.25 â€” Billed as â€œa powerful new tool in the Go diagnostics toolboxâ€, the â€˜flight recorderâ€™ continuously collects execution traces and buffers the past few seconds, letting you capture exactly the window of time needed to diagnose a problem after itâ€™s alreadyÂ happened.

Carlos Amedee and Michael Knyszek

Cloud Infrastructure: Startup toÂ Scale â€” Deploy and scale apps with containers, Supabase, AWS, Terraform, and CI/CD pipelines. Go from startup speed to enterprise-grade reliability through the three phases of growth: Startup, Growth, andÂ Scale.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Accepted! Go Proposals Distilled â€” A new series of blog posts covering accepted Go language proposals â€” so you can get up to speed with things coming to future versions of Go without having to read the entire proposal. So far Anton has covered maphash.Hasher and new(expr).

Anton Zhiyanov

IN BRIEF:

  • The Traefik project celebrates its tenth anniversary with a look at how it's matured, grown, and become one of the best known Go-powered infrastructure tools.

  • JetBrains offers a preview of its new Islands theme coming to its IDEs, including GoLand â€“ you can try it now, however.

ğŸ“ŠÂ 'We Tried Go's Experimental Green Tea Garbage Collector and It Didn't Help Performance' â€” For Doltâ€™s use case (which is quite specific), the experimental â€˜Green Teaâ€™ garbage collector you can opt to use in Go 1.25 provided no real benefits, but your mileage may vary so itâ€™s worth tryingÂ out.

Zach Mushrave (Dolt)

Starving, Sleeping, and Yielding: Understanding Go's Scheduler â€” â€œWriting concurrent programs in Go is easy, but understanding the behaviour (or, more frequently, misbehaviour) of those programs is anotherÂ matter.â€

John Arundel

3 Critical TTL Patterns for In-Memory Caching â€” Leaning on the authorâ€™s own Hot library that provides fast in-memory caching for GoÂ apps.

Samuel Berthe

âš¡ Supercharge Postgres: 2PB Scale & 1.5t Metrics/Day â€” TigerData makes Postgres the fastest database for modern workloads: 2PB scale, 1.5T metrics/day, no blackÂ boxes.

TigerData sponsor

ğŸ“º OpenCV for Go and WebAssembly with Ron Evans â€“ A live 90-minute session about computer vision with Ron Evans (of TinyGo and GoCVÂ fame). OpenCV Live

ğŸ“„ The new() Function Will Take an Expression in GoÂ 1.26 Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Build a Water Simulation in Go with raylib-go Tim Little

ğŸ“„ Register Allocation in the Go Compiler Vladimir Makarov

ğŸ“„ Slice Tails Don't Grow Forever Ted Unangst

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Do 2.0: Type-Safe Dependency Injection Toolkit â€” A library that provides the dependency injection design pattern and uses generics instead of reflection in order to provide a type-safe API. If youâ€™re already a Do user, thereâ€™s a guide for upgrading from v1.x to v2.0 to follow. GitHubÂ repo.

Samuel Berthe

Failsafe: Fault Tolerance, Resilience Patterns & Policies â€” A library for building fault-tolerant apps where you can wrap code in various resilience policies such as Retry, CircuitBreaker, RateLimiter, Timeout, and Fallback. Releases in recent weeks add several new features including usage tracking (to enforce fairness) and execution budgets for setting a maximum â€˜budgetâ€™ for retries or hedges across aÂ system.

Jonathan Halterman

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ Tuple - how developers at Shopify, Figma, and Stripe collaborate on code. Stop dictating and take control withÂ Tuple.

PegoMock 4.3: A Powerful Yet Simple Mocking Framework â€” Brings an easy-to-read DSL to mocking. You can do stubbing and argument matching, asÂ well.

Peter GÃ¶tz
